Sorry for disappearing and not answering some of the questions that 
came back. I got tied up really bad with the project I am working on.

Anyhow, I finally got the problem fixed. Initially I had some 
problems with it because I am using ANT, but I figured out WHY I was 
having the problem and resolved it. Here's what I did:

1) Installed ANT and configured accordingly (remember to install the 
   option tasks jar as well).
2) Installed JUnit.
   2.1) Copied junit.jar to $ANT_HOME/lib so that <junit> optional
        task would work.
   2.2) Copied junit.jar to $APP_HOME/lib, which is where I store all
        of my 3rd party jars, that way JUnit would work with forked
        processes from ANT.
   2.3) Extracted the file excluded.properties from junit.jar into 
        $APP_HOME/lib and added entries for org.w3c.dom.* and 
        org.xml.sax.*
3) Updated my ANT scripts to make sure that my <junit> task had 
   fork="yes" in its attributes.
4) Updated my ANT scripts so that the <classpath> referenced by my 
   <junit> task included $APP_HOME/lib/excluded.properties before 
   anything else.

I like this approach because it means I can leave the original 
junit.jar intact and I can add new elements to the file without 
having to constantly update the JAR file. 

The gotcha I was running into was with the fork="yes" attribute on 
the <junit> task. I think this may have been caused by ANT having 
already loaded the XML bits so running JUnit in the same JVM instance 
may have been problematic. Before I added that attribute I could 
output the excluded property's contents and would see the entries for 
org.w3c.dom.* and org.xml.sax.*, but I kept getting the same error... 
Now that I've added that attribute the only exceptions I'm getting 
are from my own code.... which means.... I'm back to the grind... :)

Thanks,

Sam W.
